bestBHT.bht: In this striking contrast, the heavenly glory of the Mount of Transfiguration sharply contrasts with the valley of despair and doubt where the disciples find themselves. The scribes, ever eager to undermine the disciples, gleefully question Jesus' power to heal the demon-possessed boy. Jesus and the three disciples arrive in the midst of this dispute, silencing the insolence of the scribes. The disciples' inability to heal the boy becomes a test of their faith, providing an opportunity for Jesus to reveal His divine authority and compassion.

Henry Alford: There is hardly such another contrast to be found in the Gospel as this, between the open heaven and the sons of glory on the mount, and the valley of tears with its terrible forms of misery and pain and unbelief."
The scribes were probably boasting over the disciples, and reasoning from their inability to that of their Master also.
I have already in the notes to Matthew spoken of the noble use made of this contrast in the last and grandest picture of the greatest of painters—the Transfiguration of Raffaele.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This was 'on the next day, when they were come down from the hill.' The Transfiguration appears to have taken place at night."

No doubt these cavillers were twitting the apostles of Jesus with their inability to cure the demoniac boy of whom we are presently to hear, and insinuating doubts even of their Master's ability to do it."
They, zealous for their Master's honor, would no doubt refer to His past miracles in proof of the contrary.
Marvin Vincent: The scribes. The particularizing of the scribes as the questioners, and verses 15, 16, are peculiar to Mark.
John Calvin: The Jews, on account of their perverse malice, do not deserve to be any longer endured.
It was an extraordinary display of outrageous impiety united with equally base ingratitude.
The insolence of the scribes is restrained by his presence, for, when they are asked what is the matter in dispute, they have not a word to say.
Archibald T. Robertson: It was just like the professional scribes to take keen interest in the failure of the nine disciples to cure this poor boy.
They gleefully nagged and quizzed them.
Jesus and the three find them at it when they arrive in the plain.
John Gill: He saw a great multitude about them.
Insulting them, on account of their inability to dispossess a dumb spirit.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 9:14, there is a stark contrast between the glorious scene of the Transfiguration and the valley of despair where the disciples are met with a suffering boy possessed by a demon. The scribes, known for their tendency to boast and to undermine the disciples, seize this opportunity to ridicule them and even question Jesus' ability to heal the boy. Meanwhile, Jesus, Peter, James, and John find the disciples engaged in this argument upon their descent from the mountain. The insolence of the scribes is silenced when Jesus intervenes and asks them about the dispute. Ultimately, the disciples' inability to heal the boy serves as a test to their faith and an opportunity for Jesus to reveal His divine power.

The stark contrast between the heavenly Mount of Transfiguration and the earthly valley of despair is striking in this passage. The scribes, known for their inclination to boast, take pleasure in taunting the disciples and questioning Jesus' power to heal the demon-possessed boy. Jesus, Peter, James, and John encounter this dispute when they come down from the mountain, putting an end to the insolence of the scribes. The disciples' inability to heal the boy becomes a test of their faith and an occasion for Jesus to demonstrate his divine authority and compassion.

Jesus and the three disciples arrive in the midst of this dispute, silencing the insolence of the scribes. The disciples' inability to heal the boy becomes a test of their faith, providing an opportunity for Jesus to reveal His divine authority and compassion.

Jesus and the three disciples find the disciples engaged in this dispute upon their descent from the mountain.
